paragraphs.text:
%md

# The World

by Anish Singh
blog site: [Zeppelin Notes](https://zeppelinnotes.blogspot.com)
![Image](http://belltimemagazine.ie/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/world.jpg)

#### Introduction

**The World** is a notebook describing the analysis of data, done on the various data sets made available by the World Bank for use by developers. The World Bank lists a large set of indicators(topics) to choose from, data is categorized into countries, timeframes and regions. The analysis performed in this notebook selects some of the indicators relevant to the subjects considered and attempts to find out the relationships among the various indicators that affect a particular subject. The results of the analysis enable comparison among the various regions of the world in terms of the subjects and the changes or the progress made by a region over the time frame considered.

A *subject*(as stated above) refers to the broad categorization of the various aspects that may affect a region of the world in general. Three subjects have been considered for performing analysis for this notebook, they are : Growth, World Population and Energy. Each subject may be comprised of various indicators, as an example consider World Population, which has the following component indicators:  Total Population, Urban Population, Rural Population, Population Growth and so on. Apart from the component indicators, each subject is found to have few dependent indicators, for example World Population will depend on Birth Rate, Mortality Rate and Life Expectancies. The analysis aims to find relationships between these indicators and their affect on one another and visualize the results where ever possible. The methods employed for choosing the subjects and their associated indicators from the raw list of indicators have been described in detail on the blog site mentioned above.

The notebook uses Apache Spark for the analysis of data and the visualization capabilities of Apache Zeppelin.

A subject(as stated above) refers to the broad categorization of the various aspects that may affect a region of the world in general. paragraphs.text:
%md

## 1. Growth in the World
![Image](http://iveybusinessjournal.com/wp-content/uploads/2007/07/iStock_000042856622_Large.jpg)

The first subject to be considered is the Growth that has taken place in the world over the last decade or so. There are a few component indicators that indicate the extent of growth while there is another set of indicators that are responsible for this growth. The first section in this notebook performs analysis of these indicators and tries to find the relationships among them.

We will first perform an exploratory analysis on the data(the component indicators) and get an idea about what the data looks like. This will involve examining the **GDP**([Gross Domestic Product](http://www.investopedia.com/terms/g/gdp.asp)) to get to know how it has been varying over the last few years for the different regions of the world.

%sh         #this paragraph loads the datasets needed for this subject analysis

#create the parent directory to house the data that will be used in the analysis
mkdir ~/ZeppelinData

#create the directory for the Growth data sets
mkdir ~/ZeppelinData/Growth

#get the data sets used in the analysis

#get the data sets used in the component indicators analysis
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Growth/GDPperCapita.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/NY.GDP.PCAP.CD?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Growth/GDPEnergyUse.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/EG.GDP.PUSE.KO.PP.KD?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Growth/GDPatMarketPrices.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/NY.GDP.MKTP.CD?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json" 
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Growth/GDPperPersonEmployed.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/SL.GDP.PCAP.EM.KD?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Growth/GDPGrowth.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/NY.GDP.MKTP.KD.ZG?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"

#get the data sets used in the dependent indicators analysis
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Growth/Exports.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/NE.EXP.GNFS.ZS?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Growth/FDI.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/BX.KLT.DINV.CD.WD?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Growth/EmpPopRatio.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/SL.EMP.TOTL.SP.ZS?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Growth/CPIA.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/IQ.CPA.ECON.XQ?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"

#remove the first lines from the data sets
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Growth/GDPperCapita.json
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Growth/GDPEnergyUse.json
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Growth/GDPatMarketPrices.json
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Growth/GDPperPersonEmployed.json
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Growth/GDPGrowth.json

sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Growth/Exports.json
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Growth/FDI.json
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Growth/EmpPopRatio.json
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Growth/CPIA.json

//get the name of the user's home directory to be able to fetch the data for all data loading paragraphs
val homeDir = z.input("Home Directory", "anish").toString

result.msg: homeDir: String = anish

paragraphs.text:
//load the GDP data and form the schema for all the component indicators and get the tables for analysis
val gdpPerCapita = sqlContext.read.json("/home/" + homeDir + "/ZeppelinData/Growth/GDPperCapita.json")
val gdpPersonEmp = sqlContext.read.json("/home/" + homeDir + "/ZeppelinData/Growth/GDPperPersonEmployed.json")
val gdpMarketPrc = sqlContext.read.json("/home/" + homeDir + "/ZeppelinData/Growth/GDPatMarketPrices.json")
val gdpEnergyUse = sqlContext.read.json("/home/" + homeDir + "/ZeppelinData/Growth/GDPEnergyUse.json")
val gdpGrowth    = sqlContext.read.json("/home/" + homeDir + "/ZeppelinData/Growth/GDPGrowth.json")

gdpGrowth.registerTempTable("GrowthGDP")
gdpEnergyUse.registerTempTable("EnergyUseGDP")
gdpMarketPrc.registerTempTable("MarketPrcGDP")
gdpPersonEmp.registerTempTable("PersonEmpGDP")
gdpPerCapita.registerTempTable("PerCapitaGDP")

//load the dependent indicators for the Growth data 
val exports = sqlContext.read.json("/home/" + homeDir + "/ZeppelinData/Growth/Exports.json")
val fdiData = sqlContext.read.json("/home/" + homeDir + "/ZeppelinData/Growth/FDI.json")
val epRatio = sqlContext.read.json("/home/" + homeDir + "/ZeppelinData/Growth/EmpPopRatio.json")
val cpia    = sqlContext.read.json("/home/" + homeDir + "/ZeppelinData/Growth/CPIA.json")  

exports.registerTempTable("Exports")
fdiData.registerTempTable("FDIData")
epRatio.registerTempTable("EPRatio")
cpia.registerTempTable("CPIA")

paragraphs.title: Growth GDP
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select date, value from GrowthGDP where date <> 2015

%md 
The graphs above indicate that the GDP of all other factors( per Capita, Energy Use, Person Employed and Market Prices) are independent of the World 
Growth GDP. All of the other GDP(s) (other than the World Growth) take a slump in the year 2004 and are on the rise there after, on the contrary the World Growth GDP remains steady in the same year but dips down to an all time low for the year 2009. The graphs reveal strong resemblance in the growth patterns of the GDP(s) of Market Prices, per Capita and per Person Employed which grow steadily after 2004. The GDP per unit of Energy Use also takes a dip for the year 2010 but grows thereafter.

Shown below is the plot of Growth GDP which shows the individual contributions of the various regions of the World to the GDP over the last seven years. From the plot, it is evident that the developing countries of East Asia and Pacific region have been the greatest contributors to the GDP, followed by the Arab World and the East Asia and Pacific region of all income levels. On the other hand, the Euro region has the least contributions to the GDP for all the consecutive recent years. This obsesrvation is well explained by the vast differences in the populations of the respective regions and the consequent differing capacities to contribute to the GDP.

%md
The last plot of GDP, the GDP per Capita plot for the various regions of the World has been shown below and depicts an expected contrasting situation
as compared to the GDP plot above. The Euro region has highest contributions to the GDP per Capita for all the recent consecutive years and it leads the other regions of the world by a huge margin. This is indicative of the standards of living in the region and a consequence of having lesser population than the rest of the World. The developing regions of the East Asia and the Pacific regions rank last in all of the recent years beacuse the total GDP of the region gets divided by the huge population of the region. The Central Europe and the Baltics region distinctly stands at the second highest position again due to its capacity to produce goods and services and less population compared to the regions below it.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Analysis of Factors affecting Growth

We proceed to examine the factors that have been responsible for the changes and the variations in the GDP. The first of the many [factors](http://www.scmspune.ac.in/chapter/Chapter%203.pdf) to be considered that affect the GDP of a region is the Export Capacity of the region. This is directly indicative of the goods and services produced by that country or region.

##### i. Exports
**Exports** refer to the goods and services produced in a country and that are exported to other countries as part of trade. The bar chart shown below depicts the export capacities of the various regions of the World. We see that the Central Europe and Baltics region has been rising steadily over the last few years and gets to the top most position by the year 2014. This is followed by the Arab World which was at the top in the year 2008. The region that has the least exports is the East Asia and Pacific region which has been low in exports throughout the decade.

We proceed to examine the factors that have been responsible for the changes and the variations in the GDP. The first of the many factors to be considered that affect the GDP of a region is the Export Capacity of the region. This is directly indicative of the goods and services produced by that country or region.

i. Exports

Exports refer to the goods and services produced in a country and that are exported to other countries as part of trade. The bar chart shown below depicts the export capacities of the various regions of the World. We see that the Central Europe and Baltics region has been rising steadily over the last few years and gets to the top most position by the year 2014. This is followed by the Arab World which was at the top in the year 2008. The region that has the least exports is the East Asia and Pacific region which has been low in exports throughout the decade.

paragraphs.title: Growth GDP vs. Exports
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select (E.value/10) as Export, G.value as GDP, E.country from Exports E, GrowthGDP G where (E.country = G.country) and (E.date = G.date)

%md 
Calculating the correlation between the export values and the GDP values will give us a better picture of the relation between the two quantities. In
the paragraph below, we attempt to calculate the correlation between the values and get the Karl Pearson's correlation coefficient for the two quantities as 0.1419 which indicates a positive relation between the quantities. Therefore, the GDP of a region can, to some extent, be explained on the basis of the exports of the region as the  exports are indicative of the goods and the services produced in the region.

The result patterns are largely the same for all the consecutive years.

paragraphs.text:
%md
The plot shown below has GDP per Person Employed on the y-axis and the Employment to Population ratio on the x-axis. The various regions of the world
tend to form their own clusters as is evident in the plot, with different changes in the GDP per Person Employed as the Employment to Population Ratio changes. Some of the regions show positive correlation, while one other(namely East Asia and Pacific) region shows negative correlation.

The [GDP per Person Employed](http://unstats.un.org/unsd/mdg/Metadata.aspx?IndicatorId=0&SeriesId=757#) is defined as the ratio of total Output of Goods and Services divided by the Labour input. For the East Asia and Pacific region, if the net output increases slowly as compared to the increasing employed population, a negative correlation will result which is what is indicated in the plot. Other regions show positive correlation, because their output increases with the increase in the Employment to Population Ratio. The Carribean region shows the least positive correlation between the two variables.

paragraphs.title: GDP per Person Employed vs. Employment to Population Ratio
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select E.value as EtoPRatio, (P.value/1000) as PersonEmployedGDP, E.country from EPRatio E, PersonEmpGDP P where (E.date = P.date) and (E.country = P.country)

%md
##### iv. Country Policy and Intitutional Assessment(CPIA)

The [Country Policy and Insitutional Assessment](https://knoema.com/WBCPIA2014/country-policy-and-institutional-assessment-2015?country=1000310-india) value is an annual assessment of the quality of a country's present policy and instituional
framework and it measures how sustainable, poverty reducing and supportive the framework of a country is. As many as sixteen factors about the country are taken into consideration while calculating the CPIA values. These values are measured on a scale of (1=low) to (6=high) and are indicative of how favourable the growth in a country is.

Shown below is a histogram of the CPIA values of the different regions of the world that enables easy comparison of the institutional policies in the respective regions. The Europe region does not measure the CPIA value and therefore has been shown to have zero value. For the other regions, we observe that East Asia and Pacific, and the Caribbean samll states score good with a value above 3, followed by the Arab World. For all of the regions there is a lot of scope for improvement as the highest value that can be attained is 6 and all the regions are just around the midpoint.

paragraphs.text:
%md
We have had a look on the growth taking place in the world and the contributions of the various regions of the world. Out of all the factors considered,
the exports and the CPIA values have the greatest affect on the Growth GDP. The Employment to Population ratio directly correlates with the GDP per person employed. From the analysis, it is evident that GDP for all the indicators has been on steady rise in the recent years and will hopefully grow more in the years to come.

## 2. World Population
![Image](http://i.telegraph.co.uk/multimedia/archive/01007/england-population_1007441c.jpg)

The world population reached the 7 billion mark on October 31, 2011. Various regions have differing contributions to the population of the world. In the analysis that follows we try to investigate the population growth itself and the factors that lead to the growth.

We will first take a look at the component indicators that contitute the subject of population and see how they've been varying over the years.

paragraphs.text:
%sh

#create the directory for the Population data sets
mkdir ~/ZeppelinData/Population

#get the data sets needed for the component indicators analysis of this subject
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Population/PopGrowth.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/SP.POP.GROW?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Population/PopTotal.json  "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/SP.POP.TOTL?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Population/UrbanPop.json  "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/SP.URB.TOTL.IN.ZS?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Population/RuralPop.json  "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/SP.RUR.TOTL.ZS?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"

#get the data sets needed for the dependent indicators analysis of this subject
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Population/BirthRate.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/SP.DYN.CBRT.IN?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Population/DeathRate.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/SP.DYN.CDRT.IN?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Population/AdFerRate.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/SP.ADO.TFRT?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Population/HealthExp.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/SH.XPD.TOTL.ZS?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Population/LifeExpec.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/SP.DYN.LE00.IN?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Population/Sanitize.json  "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/SH.STA.ACSN?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"

#remove the first lines from the data sets
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Population/PopGrowth.json
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Population/PopTotal.json
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Population/UrbanPop.json
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Population/RuralPop.json

sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Population/BirthRate.json
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Population/DeathRate.json
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Population/AdFerRate.json
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Population/HealthExp.json
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Population/LifeExpec.json
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Population/Sanitize.json

//load the data into Zeppelin to perform analysis

//load the data for the component indicators analysis
val popGrowth = sqlContext.read.json("/home/" + homeDir + "/ZeppelinData/Population/PopGrowth.json")
val popTotal  = sqlContext.read.json("/home/" + homeDir + "/ZeppelinData/Population/PopTotal.json")
val urbanPop  = sqlContext.read.json("/home/" + homeDir + "/ZeppelinData/Population/UrbanPop.json")
val ruralPop  = sqlContext.read.json("/home/" + homeDir + "/ZeppelinData/Population/RuralPop.json")

popGrowth.registerTempTable("PopGrowth")
popTotal.registerTempTable("PopTotal")
urbanPop.registerTempTable("UrbanPop")
ruralPop.registerTempTable("RuralPop")

//load the data for the dependent indicators analysis
val birthRate = sqlContext.read.json("/home/" + homeDir + "/ZeppelinData/Population/BirthRate.json")
val deathRate = sqlContext.read.json("/home/" + homeDir + "/ZeppelinData/Population/DeathRate.json")
val adFerRate = sqlContext.read.json("/home/" + homeDir + "/ZeppelinData/Population/AdFerRate.json")
val healthExp = sqlContext.read.json("/home/" + homeDir + "/ZeppelinData/Population/HealthExp.json")
val lifeExpec = sqlContext.read.json("/home/" + homeDir + "/ZeppelinData/Population/LifeExpec.json")
val sanitize  = sqlContext.read.json("/home/" + homeDir + "/ZeppelinData/Population/Sanitize.json")

birthRate.registerTempTable("BirthRate")
deathRate.registerTempTable("DeathRate")
adFerRate.registerTempTable("AdFerRate")
lifeExpec.registerTempTable("LifeExpec")
sanitize.registerTempTable("Sanitize")

paragraphs.text:
%md
##### i. Total Population

We know that the world population has been growing, lets have a look at exactly how its been growing over the last few years. In the graph shown below, there is a slight slump for the year 2003, otherwise the population has been growing steadily since 2004.

result.msg:
i. Total Population

We know that the world population has been growing, lets have a look at exactly how its been growing over the last few years. In the graph shown below, there is a slight slump for the year 2003, otherwise the population has been growing steadily since 2004.

paragraphs.title: Total Population
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select date, value as TotalPopulation from PopTotal where date <> 2015

%md
##### ii. Urban and Rural Population
Shown below are the individual contributions of the urban and the rural populations to the total world population over the recent years. This graph is well explained and presents a progressive picture of the world : the rural population has been sharply declining after 2003, while the urban population has been rising steadily after 2004. Rural populations do suffer from diseases and other death causing factors but much of this decline in the population can be explained on the basis of the fact that rural populations migrate to cities in search of better employment opportunities and a large number of rural settlements are being converted to sub-urban and urban townships.

result.msg:
ii. Urban and Rural Population

Shown below are the individual contributions of the urban and the rural populations to the total world population over the recent years. This graph is well explained and presents a progressive picture of the world : the rural population has been sharply declining after 2003, while the urban population has been rising steadily after 2004. Rural populations do suffer from diseases and other death causing factors but much of this decline in the population can be explained on the basis of the fact that rural populations migrate to cities in search of better employment opportunities and a large number of rural settlements are being converted to sub-urban and urban townships.

paragraphs.title: Urban and Rural Population
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select R.value as RuralPopu, U.value as UrbanPopu, R.date as Year from RuralPop R, UrbanPop U where (R.country = U.country) and (R.date = U.date) and (R.date <> 2015)

%md
##### iii. Population Growth

Shown next is the population growth graph of the various regions of the world which gives a clear picture of how the population has been growing in the various parts of
the world. As evident from the graph, there are three broad classifcations in terms of the population growth namely : the Arab world, East Asia and Pacific region and lastly the Europe region. The population growth rates have remained fairly contant over the years and are [expected to decline](http://blogs.worldbank.org/futuredevelopment/rapid-slowdown-population-growth) over the next few years.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Analysis of Factors affecting Population

We shall now examine the factors that affect population growth in the various regions of the world. We begin with health expenditures in the various parts of the world.

##### i. Health Expenditure
As the heading suggests, health expenditure refers to the expenses incurred for medical treatments. We first try to find the dependence of the growth of urban population on the health expenses and the regions that have above average health expenditures.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Two important facts are revealed in the paragraphs above, firstly the urban population and the health expenditures show a high positive correlation. This means
that poeple living in the cities are able to maintain the urban population by spending well on their health. The health expenditure may involve life saving medical treatments from injuries, diseases and illness, thereby keeping the population stable.

Secondly, the Arab World which has the highest population growth rate, largely does not depend on health expenditures for its population growth as its health spending is below mean for all the years. The Europe region, on the other hand, has the greatest(maximum) spending on health but still has its population growth rate low for all the consecutive years. The East Asia and the Pacific region also has its health spending slighlty above the mean for all the years and evidently remains steady in the population growth graph.

More will be revealed when we examine the birth and death rates.

paragraphs.text:
%md
From the above graph, we observe that the death rates have remained fairly constant over the recent years for the different regions of the world. Death
Rates are the highest for the Europe region and lowest for the Arab World. This correctly confirms the outcomes of the preceding paragraphs; the Arab World has little health expenditure beacuse there may be lesser factors causing deaths in the region and still it is able to achieve the highest population growth rate. Europe has the highest health expenses beacause of the prevelance of more death causing factors and consequently has low population growth rate. As for the East Asia and Pacific region, health expenses slighlty above the mean value enable it to cope with the death causing factors resulting in a moderate death rate.

##### iii. Birth Rates
Birth Rates also play a significant role in the population growth of the world and it is the factor that we examine next. The graph below shows the birth rates for the various regions of the world over the recent years.

paragraphs.text:
%md
The birth rate graph above is in complete agreement with the results of the preceding paragraphs, the Arab World has the highest birth rate and due to
less prevelance of death causing factors has the greatest population growth rate while Europe with the least birth rate and more death causing factors has the least population growth rate. The East Asia and Pacific region lies midway.

Lets try to find out how the Birth Rates and the Adoloscent Fertility Rates are related. For this purpose, we compute the Karl Pearson's coefficient of correlation between the adoloscent fertility rates and the birth rates.

paragraphs.title: Birth Rates vs. Adoloscent Fertility Rates
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select A.value as AdoloscentFertility, B.value as BirthRates, B.country from AdFerRate A, BirthRate B where (A.country = B.country) and (A.date = B.date)

%md
The adoloscent fertility rates and the birth rates show a high positive correlation value of 0.7419. The fertility rates are the maximum for the
Caribbean region but the birth rate is not as much. The Euro region has the lowest fertility rate and also the lowest birth rate value. The Arab World having a lesser fertility rate has more birth rate than the Caribbean region.

Shown below, is a graph of the increase rate of the population of the world which is defined to be the difference between the birth rate and the death rate. This graph exactly coincides with the population growth graph which also shows the growth rate of Europe to be negative(higher death rate than the birth rate), the rest of the regions of the world although on the positive side, have slightly decreasing increase rates. In regions like the Arab World with a high positive increase rate, the governments may be burdened with the increasing population. It can be noticed that none of the regions show an increasing growth rate in the population.

paragraphs.text:
%md
The pie chart shown above presents a very clear picture of the various regions of the world with improved sanitization facilities. We can easily notice
that Europe, comprising the Euro region and Central Europe and the Baltics region, forms the largest share of the chart above. Coincidingly, the life expectancy plot also puts Europe on the top. The next largest share is that of the Asia and Pacific region, which also has second position in the plot above. Lastly, the Arab World that has the last position in the plot has the least share in the pie chart. The Arab region although has least access to improved sanitization facilities and ranks lowest in the life expectancy plot, still has the highest populattion growth rate. This clearly indicates that surroundings form an important factor in deciding how good life in the region is.

Although the world population is growing as a whole, the rate of population growth is declining. Many nations in Western Europe (and the EU as a whole) today would have declining populations if it were not for international immigration. The total population of the continent of Europe (including Russia and other non-EU countries) peaked around the year 2000 and has been falling since 2004. [Population Matters](http://www.populationmatters.org/?gclid=CPn00Ovj78wCFdaGaAodknoNiA) is an organization that deals with matters concerning population and its impacts on the society.

paragraphs.text:
%sh 

#create the directory to store the data sets used in this analysis
mkdir ~/ZeppelinData/Energy

#get the datasets needed in the component indicators analysis
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Energy/EnergyUse.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/EG.USE.PCAP.KG.OE?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Energy/FossilUse.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/EG.USE.COMM.FO.ZS?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Energy/Renewable.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/EG.FEC.RNEW.ZS?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Energy/NuclearEn.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/EG.USE.COMM.CL.ZS?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"

#get the datasets used in the dependent indicators analysis
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Energy/Electric.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/EG.USE.ELEC.KH.PC?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Energy/NResRent.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/NY.GDP.TOTL.RT.ZS?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Energy/Industry.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/SL.IND.EMPL.MA.ZS?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Energy/GNIncome.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/NY.GNP.PCAP.CD?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"
wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/Energy/Intnsity.json "http://api.worldbank.org/countries/indicators/EG.EGY.PRIM.PP.KD?per_page=100&date=2000:2016&format=json"

#remove the first lines from the datasets
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Energy/EnergyUse.json
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Energy/FossilUse.json
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Energy/Renewable.json
sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Energy/NuclearEn.json

sed -i 's/\[{"page":1,"pages":40,"per_page":"100","total":3968},//g' ~/ZeppelinData/Energy/Electric.json

paragraphs.text:
%md
##### i. Energy Use
We shall first see the changes in the net energy use patterns for the world for the last decade or so. The graph below shows that the energy used per capita took a jump in the year 2003 and reached its peak in the year 2006, decreased in the next year and has remained fairly constant since then.

result.msg:
i. Energy Use

We shall first see the changes in the net energy use patterns for the world for the last decade or so. The graph below shows that the energy used per capita took a jump in the year 2003 and reached its peak in the year 2006, decreased in the next year and has remained fairly constant since then.

paragraphs.title: Energy Use(per Capita)
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select date as Year, value as NetEnergyPerCapita from EnergyUse where date between '2000' and '2013' and country.value <> 'Europe & Central Asia (all income levels)'

%md
##### ii. Fossil Fuel Energy Consumption
The graph below shows the fossil fuel energy consumption for the various parts of the world. Here again, the Arab World leads the other regions and its fossil fuel(non -renewable resource) consumption has largely remained constant. The proven oil reserves in Saudi Arabia are the second largest in the world, estimated to be 268 billion barrels. The Caribbean Small States region experienced a decline in the consumption between the years 2004 and 2007, but it has been increasing ever since. The fossil fuel consumption for the East Asia and Pacific region and the Central Europe and the Baltics region attained a common value for the year 2006, but it decreased thereafter for the Europe region and has been increasing for the East Asia and the Pacific region. The Euro region stands distinctly at the bottom most position and has had a noticeable decline in its fossil fuel consumption.

Saudi Arabia is the fastest growing electricity consumer in the Arab World. Electricity generation is 65% from oil, 27% from natural gas and 8% from steam. Generation capacity is approximately 55 GW.

paragraphs.text:
%md
##### iii. Renewable Energy Consumption
The graph below shows the renewable energy usage by the various regions of the world over the last decade. The East Asia and Pacific region accounts for the greatest usage of the renewable energy followed by Europe, however the difference is that Asian and Pacific regions have been decreasing their usage of renewable resources while Europe has been increasing it. The Arab World and the Caribbean states have the least contributions to the renewable energy usage because their energy demands are well met by other non-renewable resources, especially in case of the Arab World which has vast reserves of oil and natural gas and does not need any other resource.

paragraphs.text:
%md
##### iv. Alternative and Nuclear Energy Use
As shown in the graph below, the Europe region leads the other regions in terms of the nuclear and alternative energy use by a large margin and this well explains how its demands for energy are met even after staying low in the fossil fuel and renewable energy consumption, the graph indicates that nuclear energy use in the region is on the rise. This is followed by the East Asian and the Pacific countries which contribute to some extent to the usage of nuclear and alternative energy sources. Lastly, we have the Arab World and the Caribbean countries whose energy demands are fully met by fossil fuels and hence they don't contribute much to the nuclear energy use.

paragraphs.text:
%md
In the analysis of the component indicators above, we have been able to see that the energy usage(in its various forms) can be grouped into the 
following three regions by the proportion of usage:-
1) The Arab World and the Caribbean Small States with the largest share of fossil fuel usage.
2) The East Asian and the Pacific Countries with the greatest share of renewable energy usage.
3) Lastly the Europe region based on the largest share of alternative and nuclear energy usage.

Shown below is a bar chart that presents the disparity in the usages of the various forms of energy throughout the world(year wise). As is evident, the usage of fossil fuels by far exceeds the usage of the other means of energy generation. paragraphs.title: Energy Use(various forms)
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select N.date, F.value as Fossil, R.value as Renewables, N.value as Nuclear_Alternatives from FossilUse F, Renewable R, NuclearEn N where ((F.date = N.date) and (N.date = R.date) and F.date between '2000' and '2012') and (N.country = R.country and F.country = N.country)

%md
#### Analysis of Factors affecting Energy Demands
We will now examine some of the factors that influence the energy demands.

##### i. Electric Power Consumption(kWh per Capita)
To begin with we will first look into the electric power consumption patterns of the various regions of the world, and try to correlate the outcomes with the demands of energy expressed by the respective regions. Europe has the largest per Capita demand power consumption and leads the other regions by a huge margin. The rest of the regions have nearly the same consumption pattern(increasing). After the year 2010, the East Asia and the Pacific region overtook the Arab region in the per Capita power consumption. This is again indicative of the standards of living in the Europe region as it also had the highest per Capita GDP. Also, since Europe has the least population, the total energy consumption when divided by the population gives the greatest value.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Large proportion of electric power consumption is due to industries. The paragraph above lists the regions that have above mean indusrial employment for
any of the years from 2000, to give an idea of the demand for electric power consumption. The results coincide with the graph of electric power consumption in the paragraph above it. For all of the years, Europe has had above mean industrial employment and this is a consequence of the industrialized and developed economies of Europe that have heavy industrial employment. The East Asia and Pacific region has above mean industrial employment only for the years 2003-2007 and hence had a growing demand of electric power consumption during those years. Finally, the Arab World has industrial demand for energy above mean only as recently as 2011 and hence its demand for electric power has remained almost constant(only slightly increasing).


##### ii. Total Natural Resource Rent
[Resource Rent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resource_rent) is defined to be the surplus value after all costs and normal returns have been accounted for in terms of the natural resources such as oil rent, natural gas rent, coal rent and minerals rent. It can also be conceptualized as abnormal or supernormal profit. The pie charts below depict this indicator for the last three years. The Arab world which occupied the largest portion in 2012 is seen to be increasing its share in the next years, while the Caribbean states experianced a decline. Europe combined has the least share, with the Euro region diminished to a thin unseen slice of the pie chart. Asian and the Pacific region also form small portions of the chart.

The pie charts are in complete agreement with the resutls in the preceding paragraphs, the Arab World experiences a surplus in the total natural resources rent because of low energy demand and usage and an excess of the natural resources, as we saw in the table above, the Arab region does not have above average industrial emloyment for all the recent years. While Europe that forms the smallest chunk of the pie chart has no surplus at all due to heavy industrial usage of energy and consequent energy demand. The East Asia and the Pacific region is able to maintain surplus(in small amounts) because it did not have above average industrial employment for the years shown below. The results are also indicative of the fuel export capacities of the various regions, the Arab World is by far and large the greatest exporter of oil and natural gas.

paragraphs.text:
%md
##### iii. Gross National Income
The [Gross National Income](www.investopedia.com/terms/g/gross-national-income-gni.asp) is measured to be the sum of the value added by all the producers(resident in a nation), plus any product taxes not included in output, plus income received from abroad. We plot a graph between the energy use values and the gross national income values(both measured per Capita), to get an idea about how the national incomes affect the energy use values. The various regions of the world appear distinctly on the graph, with a positive correlation. The Euro region that has the highest gross national income also has the greatest energy demand because the region's income levels support the consumption of that amount of energy. The Caribbean region that had relatively less national income peaked in its energy demand with values close to the Euro region. The rest of the regions have overlapping gross national income and energy use values. To measure the exact value of correlation between the two values we calculate the Karl Pearson's correlation coefficient for the two quantities which turns out to be 0.664(a high positive correlation). This implies that the national incomes positively affect the tendencies of the various regions of the world to spend on their energy demands resulting in consequent consumption patterns.

paragraphs.text:
%md
##### iv. Energy Intensity Level of Primary Energy
[Energy Intensity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy_intensity) is a measure of the energy efficiency of a nation's economy. It is calculated as units of energy per unit of GDP. High energy intensities indicate a high price or cost of converting energy into GDP. Low energy intensities indicate a lower price or cost of converting energy into GDP. This is directly indicative of the efficiency of the energy utilization processes of the various regions. If a region has inefficient processes for utilizing energy then the demand remaining constant, it will not be easily met by the available resources resulting in more consumption which may lead to an apparent increase in demand than the actual. This may cause the region to have low total resource rent. On the other hand, if these processes are efficient, the demands for energy are easily met resulting in a greater value of total resource rent. This is exactly what we can observe in the plot below. The energy intensity values of the Euro region are the lowest, therefore it has a low total natural resource rent and more demand of energy than any other region. As the energy intensity values increase on the x-axis, the regions with the greater values also have slightly more total resource rent. One of the exceptions is the Arab World which despite having a low value of energy intensity, has a high value of total resource rent and this is because the demand in the region is altogether very low and demand was initially assumed to be constant.

%md
We have been able to take a look at three of the most impactful subjects of the world namely, Growth, Population and Energy. Various factors that affect
these subjects have been considered and their relationships have been examined. All of the subjects present a positive picture of the world; especially Growth. Growing population is a bit of concern due to limited resources, but the population growth rate is sharply declining. Various regions have different dominant methods of fulfilling their energy demands, however the use of renewable energy resources by the Asian and Pacific region is very appreciable. It can be hoped that other regions too will adopt sustainable means of existence without compromising on the growth so the the living standards of the various regions are elevated further and we may have a better future.
